element_texts.text: Completed

My very dear Isaac & Nettie                                                                 Bangor Nov. 10 /56
I intended to write to you before I left Milo but delays and neglects are not very uncommon things with me. I had a fine visit there grew well & strong on Albina's pumpkin bread it is I really believe very healthy. I never before saw a child grow smart and fleshy as Percie did while he was there in my life you know how weak his bowels have always been and ever since he was so sick

Till we went to Milo and for some days after we could never allow him to eat much else but bread - Albina had a fine parcel of dried Raspberry leaves and I gave P. P. Tea made of it 2 or 3 weeks constantly I put in 1 or 2 spoon full of it very strong in a cup of milk sweeten'd a little he lov'd it took it with his meal and at other times and soon got so that he could eat anything that any of the children ate but he prefer'd before anything else the Brown Bread made of stew'd Pumpkin and indian meal & he has grown very fat & large & strong.

top of page Thanksgiving day Dear Nettie how much we have yet to be thankful for- O if Isaac's life and health is spar'd after what he has done this fall How I want to see the dear little Wilder & O how I want to see you all. I shall ? myself trying to imagine just how you are in your new home I think you will enjoy it - when is Isaac going to Ill. How shall I want to know every particular about your fear you wont have time & strength to tell me all Love to Anna and all her family I wrote to her when I was at Milo and recieved a letter from her hope she & you & she will take much comfort together I think you may benefit her and she you she is too impulsive quick you are more catious & deliberate when she starts on any course you must holden & consider whether it is the right one
I think you & Isaac will take great comfort in the Dr. you will like him better & better the more you get acquainted please write often to your Mother.
Completed

James is with Charles yet he had not been home since March till I went there. He has the reputation of being a very good steady young man. He has made up his mind to be a Farmer is intending to work out & get money enough as soon as he can & go out west & buy him a farm & have a home for his Mother if she should wish it - Mr. Rider is much more comfortable than I expected to see him - he says he does not suffer much pain not so much as he did months ago - tho' his cancer is fast progressing it has affected the bone so that about the middle of the jaw on the left side it is seperated & his chin fallen back 3/4 of an inch it troubled him to talk at first but he talks well enough now it has also ate clean through to his mouth just before his ear. Almeda has to dress it 3 times a day the smell is very offensive - She sleeps in the little middle bedroom - I enjoy'd my visit there better far than I expected he was very sociable & they both seem'd happy & contended. Lizzie went home last Monday. I concluded that Maria had rather not have her here this winter Almeda would rather she should be away from home if she could be at a good school she
Completed

quite a good scholar in grammar & arithmetic Probably a good school would do her more good a year or 2 hence than now
Charles still talks about selling his farm & going west - His farm tho a very good one is in just such a place that he has had no opportunity to sell & I doubt if he ever will - He talks that he shall get what he can off of it 2 or 3 years & then leave it if he can find a good place somewhere else

 Eliab took his grey horse to use a while & then sell he has now sold it for $162 1/2 - And has bought a little bit of a creature (weighs: 700) for about 60, which they extol very much. Maria is very well xxxxx but I dont believe Hattie will go away unless it is for a short time - They have got everything nicely arrang'd here to suit them all as different as may be from what it was  I am very glad to have them here if Sam'l must break up his home but O what a change I did feel very sad a while - Lucy gone all her things away & the keen apprehension that Sam'l & P. will go away  I do love Sam'l as an own Son & should feel worse perhaps about his going off - more of the feeling that when gone they
Completed

Mother Bangor Nov. 20 1856
Elyria
would be quite gone - but perhaps he'll not go far away & take Percie with him I think he will go to Minnesota next spring or summer but I have a fancy that he will not like there enough to go there to live. I am sorry I was not here when he pack'd his things to send away I fear he sent some things that you would rather not have - than to pay even the transportation - I have not heard a word said about the prices of the articles he sent

He occupies the new chamber over the kitchen tis a very pretty chamber & newly furnish'd it has the secretary that was in the sitting room - the Bureau that was in Lucy's bedroom the Clock, sink that was in the parlor chamber is has a large closet with shelves & 2 longer drawers - a little stove, a window in the roof on the South side.
The beautiful Doves that Lucy thought so much of are all gone away I cant think why unless it was that the noise of the Carpenter frightened them away you know they had 7 sent from Boston last spring & they had one left of the others - but they are all gone.
I suppose S. & E are somewhat troubled about paying a large note in Boston about this time but they dont say much about it & so we dont ask them probably they'll get thro' with it somehow as they have done before
Completed

Mother Metcalf
Bangor Dec. 1856
Elyria
My Dear Children
I suppose you have heard of my being suddenly & violently sick with inflammation in chest - the Pleurie Liner  & I don't know what not inflam'd right lung entirety in active (perhaps I don't express it right) But the pain was dreadful & the laboring & raging of brain in half sleep almost as bad - after trying Dr. Paine as was E's choice  awhile he went for Dr. McRuen - He thought I might not live but a day or two - among other remedys they put flannel wet in boiling hot Lineament or as hot as fingers could get it on to my side & shoulder from the 5th day it subsided very fast - and - by absorption a very uncommon case the Dr. said especially in a person so old They wrote to C. he came & stay'd 4 days, walking &c with utmost solicitude O I have had every care & attention - What Children I have - was ever Mother so bless'd & Hattie so efficient - good & kind
Completed

now what shall I render to God for all his rich mercies - I will even as I have throw myself all impotent as I am unto his arms. - I have felt such peaceful trust - such quiet hope - O May it not be at last as the spiders web - Flow precious how beyond expression glorious to be in Christ & kept by him, when so vile to last without him
Now Anna let me caution you about your health - I suspect you have many times in years gone by taken medicine - when what you needed instead was rest - relaxation, from severe mental effort - by which means you have so injured the healthful tone of your stomach that you need to be comfort  I wish you wantd as much as in you lies avoid medicine you have a good constitution, try to keep it so
My cough & trouble in my side are almost gone I've only weakness & am growing stronger every day Do all write to your
Mother
Completed

Scrawled on top:
Mother
Jan. 8 57
Bangor Jan 8th /57
My Dear Son,
We receiv'd letters from you last night - which as usual gladen'd our hearts I did indeed get reliev'd when I was sick wonderfully quick - Dr. Paine came here 3 or 4 times & E. went twice to him for medicine &c. between Sunday morning & tuesday night - I don't know but I should have got better if I'd had no other Dr. but I think not near as soon - They didn't feel satisfied & got Dr. McRuen wednesday & thursday I was much reliev'd not withstanding both the Dr. thought as I'm told since that I could live but a short time probably my being so old was the reason of that opinion
Tho' it was so short a time it took away my strength & flesh - I have a strong inclination you know, perhaps you'll call it pride to take care of myself i.e. not to trouble other people not to be waited upon which came on a long even before I'm aware of it - But I probably got along all the better for it
I went down stairs or rather E. carried me in just
Completed

two weeks from the time I was taken sick (tho' not again for some days) and I sat up most all day every day - and have been gaining strength can stand by - am as well now as before I was sick except that my cough is not quite gone  I have had a cough and pain, or rather sameness in my side - not bad occation'd the Dr. said by adhesion of the Lungs he saw it would near away & it does

I had too a strange sensation from the time I began to get better  I don't know as I can describe it - spasmodic or like hiccough or like catching the breath with a very sharp pain in my right side & shoulder - gone again in an instant almost but occurring at first every minute then at longer intervals till it has about ceas'd
It is wonderful that I am now so well - you and Anna & Nettie write about my going to Elyria - when Sam'l goes which he expects will be in April 

But I suppose it would not be best I shall then if I live be seventy years old - old enough to settle down at home for the rest of the time besides Albina expects to be sick in April  Almeda is in much affliction  Mr. Rider suffers I suppose very much It is difficult now for him to swallow at
Completed

all hurts him very much to swallow his food or talk probably cannot live long - & it will be even matter of rejoicing when he is releas'd & permitted to enter into the joy of his Lord to be where he is, and to behold his glory - I had a good long letter from Charles & Albina  they were all very well - sent us 2 prs of nice fat chickens  Almeda has a very hard disagreeable lot now besides great labor & care the every offensive odor in which she must live constantly  She is almost sick I fear it will wear her all out - James is boarding at Charles Everetts & attending school at the village I've had two letters from him lately he is making his calculations now to earn money as fast as he can till he gets enough to buy him a farm somewhere out west & make a home for his Mother & Lissie - has given up the idea of learning a trade - I had a letter from your uncle Pelatiah not long since he wrote that your cousin Sam'l Metcalf is in Illinois (a land speculator) Josiah has just returned from a 3 years whaling voyage.  Maria Stevens wrote me a few weeks ago that Sister Conant & Esther were well  She saw Sister Conant at the
Completed

Funeral of Esq. Russell he died instantly in his chair - Percie is all the time at my elbow - dont make my writing look much better He is a great fat boy - but I fear his mind rather cramp'd now a days for we? are, tho' very kind and pleasant & all that so sort of particular that he can have nothing to do that he may do, - any kind of plaything, litter up the room & if he has anything baby is apt to want it (we must learn him, to be kind & accommodating he has had a cold - & the croup slightly is constantly in this tight room with double windows & coal fire - He sews a little draws the chair about is thought to be rather roguish sometime,
I've had some trouble to make him mind since I've got well more than I had before, but he is on the whole a very good boy - would have him go outdoor if he had any body to play with but he dont like to go out alone - Sam'l talks now that he should take him right on to Min. with him in the spring I dont love to think of it - Little Erving stands alone gets up & walks round by the side of the house - is a knowing little fellow - S. & E. are collecting debts S. said if they could all it would pay all their debts & have their stock of goods & 4000$ left that their nominal profits in 3 years had been 1400, - but I think E. is all the time perplex'd and streightened danger of bank failing &c I think I've got my paper full
good bye from your loving Mother
Completed

Bangor Jan 15/57
My Dear Daughter,
I wrote a long letter to Isaac last week & directed it to Ducoign perhaps it will not get there till he is away from there -  not worth much if he never gets it no matters. My health is pretty good now tho' I am not near as strong as before I was sick. I have some cough and soreness in my side - but it seems to be getting better am nearly or quite as fleshy as before __ I've had a queer feeling from the time I began to get better I can hardly describe it. It was some like hiccough or catching the breath - or as I told Eliab it seem'd as if something suddenly caugh hold of the roots of my breath or occasioning attended with very sharp pain & occurring at first every few seconds then at longer & longer intervals till now only a few times a day.
Completed

E. had a letter from Isaac last night he has a proposal to sell his right of mining/coal at Du Coign and an offer of a situation there Salary 1500.00 a year all which he will have told you. Eliab says he ought to, & probably can do better than that It seems doubtful whether they could enjoy good health there that I guess he will not stay there.
Sam'l is now gone to Milo & Brownville I expect him home today if he comes I will write you the news from there - He and Eliab have made a trade E. has bought his situation here all his interest in the store &c. Poor Sam'l how unfortunate he has been But he is a Man what is a Man as the boys say and will do well yet - indeed he has always done well
I have some fears for E. it is a great undertaking for him to carry on a business involving nearly a hundred thousand a year he says even if he can succeed in paying up his debts - He says they have 4000, more due to them than they owe but a considerable part of it they probably will never get
Completed

It makes me think of Lucy (many things do) when M. first came up here (She was expecting all to be theirs I guess) E. is sincerely lovingly kind & attentive to me in every thing he ought to be to me & more too - Maria & Hattie are just as polite, as kind and attentive as they can be every thing just right.
S. thinks of taking P.P. right along to Minnesota in the Spring it makes me sad - He needs tender affectionate care which he would probably have but he needs also discipline - He is not a very stubborn child but so full of roguery it is difficult to make him mind exactly and quick but is on the whole a very good boy

Sam'l has just returned from Milo been gone 3 nights they were all well at M. & at Brownville except Mr. Rider he suffers exceedingly can take no food but liquid & that with great difficulty, Said one day that he should never try to swallow again if it was not duty - has face very much swollen but can talk tho' it hurts him a great deal. This is a poor naughty letter I am asham'd of it dont let any body see it and I'll try to do better next time
Completed

little Ewing is almost sick with a cold and teething the poor little fellow must be dress'd so fashionably that he has a hard time
It does almost seem as if Hattie think greatly looks or what she considers such of more consequence than health & Hattie's emphatically the ruling spirit here

 Much love to you all. I am expecting a letter from some of you daily
                                                                                                                            Mother

[left-hand side]It will probably be best for me not to go to Elyria next spring if I should be well Eliab talks that he shall not always stay in Bangor that he shall perhaps go next sometime if Sam'l he & Charles should all go, perhaps I will.

                                                                                                                                       good bye

James B. Searles thinks he shall go next & buy a farm as soon as he gets money enough
A.M. Metcalf Jan. 15, 57
Completed

Feb. 14 1857 Bangor
DuQuoin, Mar 5
Bangor Feb
My Dear Son Isaac
I had a good letter from you a few days since & tuesday, came yours to Eliab. I rejoice that your town is progressing so finely. It seems likely to be quite an oasis in that land of darkness. If you should conclude to stay there I think it quite likely that C. would be for going there too. Sam'l says if he were in Charles place he should leave Milo he thinks he could do better than to remain there another year says perhaps he shall coax him off to Minnesota - But it will be hard work for him to move anywhere because Albina has so little energy & fortitude about it I dont see how he can get along there it seems that he is running behind hand every year - has us'd up a great part of the money he brought from Ill. His ability or strength for labor is growing less & his family more expensive. However I feel perfectly easy about it to have him stay or go - Sam'l seems now divided to take P.P. with him but I mean to try to persuade him to leave him with me - with us
Completed

I began this several days ago but baby has been very sick so I didn't finish it  He took a very bad cold & it settled on his lungs (is teething besides) his breathing was dreadful the Dr. call'd it congestion or lung fever - After much demur & some hard speaches by Hattie because E. did not send for Dr. Payne the child growing worse in spite of Eliabs application of cold water bandages to his neck & all else that we could do E. started off & got Dr. McRuen - He bid us take a thick woolen blanket wring it out of hot water and wrap the child in it - we changed it once & kept him in it 4 hours it soothed & relieved him very soon - He was taken last saturday night 7th is now Saturday 14th pretty well again but quite feeble  So nervous & uneasy & gets tir'd so quick that Hattie has a hard time as well as the rest - Hattie has taken the babe all to herself, ever since it was 3 or 4 months old it has not slept with its mother at all  H. is so impulsive all hoighty toighty it makes the child so to but she means it all right is very kind and good & E. and Maria must be under life long obligation to her??
Completed

14th Feb 1857
Baby being sick & Maria daily expecting to be E. sent a "telagram" to Mary Ely at Hartford, She arriv'd here last evening - I think Sam & Ely will come in the spring & this will be the home for them all & a very good home it will be. E. will fix up & ornament the grounds and make it beautiful - It makes me think of dear Lucy & all her pleasing anticipations But I would not - that she should be here if the thing were possible - I have some fears for Eliab alone in a business involving a hundred thousand a year  I'm afraid he'll shall need Sam'l for at least a part to lean upon  If he does succeed in clearing away all his difficulties paying all yours & every thing it will be almost wonderful wont it? Sam'l came back from N.H. last monday has been gone about 3 weeks visiting his cousins & second cousins  He is now & will probably be for a month to come occupied as jury man - in a good time for him as
Completed

he had nothing to do E. has very little to do keeps Mr. Martin & Chapman in the store doing nothing this winter for the sake of having them the rest of the year when he does want 'em
H.W. Beecher lectur'd here two evenings this week - even I heard him thursday evening he is certainly an Orator for Norumbega Hall was crowded full & there was the most perfect stillness his Subject the Christian Commonwealth  Percie is very well & grows very fast he will not play out door as he has no one to be with him and is rather troublesome (i.e. his noise) in the house while Erving is sick

Eliab received a letter from you today "good boy well done" for writing so frequently - Be not weary in well doing 

it is growing dark I cant see what I am writing must quit or get a lamp
God bless you & keep you in all your ways
Completed

Mother Bangor Me
Feb 25 1857
Bangor Feb 28
My Dear Son
I feel like writing a little to you tho' I have nothing particularly interesting to write - we are all very well now - We have had remarkably mild weather since about the 23-24th of Feb. the very cold spell when the mercury in our thermometer was frozen and it was said downtown that it was down to 24 - The winter has all been mild with the exception of 2 or 3 very cold spells & those were short - we have rain & very soft weather sleighing about all gone about the 18th warm enough to set without a fire  from 50 to 60 above I stay at home mostly do nothing but knit & read & not much of that for it makes my head ache to read much. "The Independent" takes considerable time - I have lately read again The Rise & Progress - Have now been reading "Footprints of the Creation" & incredible as it may seem I really enjoyed it - tho' of course I couldn't understand it all - To many geological terms - I receiv'd your letter of the 15th on the 24th.
Completed

I have written one letter which you had not got when you wrote last - You say about my going to Elyria - I should love to go but would it be right - I have been hoping lately that 
Sam'l will leave Percie with me at Milo this coming summer - If he will consent to that -& then I could go to Elyria & take him with me in the fall i.e. if I am alive & well it would just suit me - & Eliab says he will go with me in the fall - but Sam'l says he knows he wont - & it seems to me that he cant

 March 1st 1857 Seventy years - How short they seem - Seventy years I have been the constant recipient of innumerable blessings! & what have I rendered - what but sin & folly  O the love of God - the unspeakable riches of his mercy His long suffering & tender mercy - Praise - Praise Eternal glory to his Name
 3rd I thought to have finished this before now but I waited supposing that I could inform you of the coming of another little responsibility by this time Eliab has been waiting & dare not go (as he wants to very much) to Boston
Completed

I had a letter from Almeda 19th Feb. Mr. Rider was failing very fast or rather he was suffering very much - I suppose has suffer'd ten times more with hunger than a person would in starving to death  It is very trying for him, he liv'd about two weeks on, only sweetened water, but when she wrote could take very thin chicken broth - O it must be very dreadful for Almeda the smell is so very offensive it seems to me it would be more than I could bear
Sam'l is making boxes to pack ins goods in is intending to carry his two bureaus & his large Secretary a Table, 3 Feather beds, lot of bedding &c &c. I suppose he has not fully decided the matter but I think he will conclude to leave Percie with me at Milo - I feel as if Percie ought to be with me at present - It was Lucys wish that he should  I would williingly go to Elyria with Sam'l if it were not that I have not been at Charles's hardly since I came from there & & have seen Almeda but very little in all the last two years - I know that I can really do her no good but I must sympathise with her in her trouble - besides I very much doubt whether Percie or I should be
Completed

as healthy at Elyria as at Milo
I want very much to be kept inform'd what your cogitations, inclinations, destination, occupations, & determinations, are - I believe I wrote you that Mary Ely is here - I have written to you pretty often & cant remember what I have written & what I have not - Maria has a large Flower stand with 4 shelves full of plants & Hattie & Mary have just been down to the greenhouse & bought 3 or 4 beautiful ones in bloom one splendid gilly flower 7 or 8 great stalks full of blossoms - E. & his folks are a very pleasant family - and all flourishing finely & I can see nothing but what E. is likely to get along bravely thro' all his perplexities if he does get all paid up & squared round to suit himself he will hold up his head wont he especially among business men
I fear I have written more nonsense than you can well afford time to read
May God be with you & keep you & bless you in all your ways
your loving Mother
Completed

Mother Bangor
May 4 .57
Bangor May 4th/57
My Dear Son
I receiv'd your good letters written when Sam'l was there & here I am yet feeling somewhat disappointed that I couldn't get to Milo before now. The Ice went out about a fortnight earlier than usual & it swept off all the Bridges & Dams on the Piscataquis The Brownville, Alder stream and Boobar brook bridges- we have had a great deal of rain so that the Streams are high & the travelling bad yet- I expect to go there in a few days now_ I shall hardly get well Settled there before the time will come when I should like to go to Elyria if I could have a good chance- There are some inconveniences about living just 4 of five months in a place it takes So much time to get pack'd up to go_ & to get settled again_ indeed the last hardly gets done at all
Completed

you enquire if I would go to Elyria in June or July_ I want to be there enough_ But should have a short time to stay at Milo & Brownville_ moreover I dont know as it would be expedient or safe to go from here there in the hottest Season_ But If I go at all I must go when I can_ you speak of Coming here have you any business that will call you this way_ If you have I should delight to go back with you_ But I Shall hear from Sam'l soon & will let you know what he says about his Father's coming_ Tho' Eliab says that I shall not go with Maj. Furber & that he will go with me next fall but I dont believe he can till December
Maria is very well and smart is now gone down to Main St on foot a shopping Sam'l told you perhaps about Eliab's quick horse & how we got thrown from the wagon. E's wrist is very weak yet._ One night last week he left him just for a few minutes _ & he run & rid himself of the wagon except the forewheels and
Completed

was gone near 2 hours before Eliab found him_ the creature is just as quick as a cat_ But E. insists that he is perfectly kind_ They have not named the baby yet._ Charles has got a little Daughter born 24th of April
Almeda has bought Mills' part of the farm for $500, & he is expecting to go west_ is hoping to get a chance to work with you_ Mills has the western Fever the worst kind_ I fear he will be greatly disappointed Almeda's calculation as with a view to James's benefit_ Means to get all she can from the place & then to sell it or leave it & go west_ But a great deal seems to depend, with them all, upon whether you get located advantageously & even Eliab says he thinks he shall not stay in Bangor more than a few years Charles has been unfortunate with his Sheep some disease among them all sick & dying_ Almeda has lost one of her Cows that she depended on for profit this summer_ C. has hir'd George Hodgskins for the Summer at 12,00 pr month
Completed

There seems to be, a more than usual, interest in the subject of religion in this City we have known of but few cases of conversion in the Central society but more in the Freewill Baptists_ Meetings in the Central Church 4 or 5 evenings in the week this 8 or 10 weeks past

 How I do miss Samuel, from the singing quoir & every where_ I have felt rather uneasy_ no not uneasy exactly- at the thought of being here since he is gone, there seems not the same reason for staying here besides Maria has her two sisters & a strong Girl She dont need for Company or help_ And it would be better for Percie now his Father is away

I have an opportunity to send this will not stop to finish it now good bye
Completed

Mother Metcalf
Bangor March 14 & 16
(Elyria Ohio)
Bangor
My Dear Son
The thing seems now to be determin'd that Percie & I spend the summers at Milo_ Anna wrote very earnestly for me to go to Elyria with Samuel but I have not been able to really think it best_ not that I should not enjoy it very much in deed_ I really cant think of such a thing as your going away from there before I see you
The question has been whether I could have any good opportunity to go in the fall but Sam'l has thought of a way_ His Father & wife are coming east to spend the Summer or part of it, & S. says I can go when they go back_ & so I can if I live & have my health_ but I had forty times rather have you or Eliab for company_ E. says he will go with me soon as the river closes but Sam'l says he dont believe he will or can 
Hattie presented me on my seventieth birthday a very handsome Silver apple knife and Eliab 
right side brought me a beautiful Gold pen & pencil but I had a nice one before that
Completed

14th,- Mr. Rider died last Tuesday [10th] was buried Thursday he has suffer'd a great deal but died very easy at the last 
Sam'l & Eliab went up to the funeral
I have written two letters to you within a month & am duely expecting one from you I should enjoy some precious privileges at Elyria or here and some comforts that I cannot expect at Milo- & indeed I expect many little anoyances there But I think it will be better for Percie to be there with the children 
He has not the goaheadativeness that Mayo had is babyish and hanging round one all the time when his father is not about- he loves to be with him when he is here 
16_ Thus far I had written & then concluded to lay it by till I reciev'd one from you & now half past nine P.M. I have just read yours of March 11th & now what shall I say to you? I want to be with you & yours & Anna
Completed

at Elyria O: how much_ But I have thought that I ought to be at Milo_ Not as Anna seems to think because of my help I could be by way of Labor for I dont expect to do much any where_ & I am aware that it would make it harder for Albina. I think it would be better for Percie
I wish I could feel fully decided about it I think I should feel easier_ I had got the manner quite settled in my mind but Anna's and your urgent entreaties rather disturbs the puddle a little

Things doubtfull are uncertain & it is uncertain whether P. would be as well there in hot weather I think he has not entirely got over the weakness of bowels occasion'd by his sickness, or else fails to govern himself as he might (makes a great deal of washing of Pants) He improv'd in health & strength very much while at Milo & has I doubt not been more healthy during the winter than he would have been if he had not gone there
Completed

I expect Almeda here by stage tomorrow & will lay my letter aside again till after she comes & gets her opinion

 Please write me immediately on receiving this & inform me when it is probable you shall have to leave home if you obtain the situation you mentioned_ Almeda came last night but I know no more what to say to you only that She is decided in the opinion that I ought not to go away this Spring_ If I could any way possibly think it best to go to Elyria this Spring I could hardly have time now to get ready_ Should want to go to Milo first- & he is going in a fortnight_ has nothing more to do but pack his goods.
 Albina has a girl engaged for 2 or 3 months_ I feel as if it must be very doubtful if I got to Elyria whether I should ever return especially if C. should ever go west & James should go west & consequently Almeda should go to_ & could I go & not go to Milo & perhaps not see the children & folks perhaps for years if ever_ Please write every thing explain all about every thing _ say if you can that you think it best that I stay till Maj. Furber goes- only I should dread to with him. God bless you all my children I want to be with you- if I could only be in two places at once   your Mother
Completed

Mother
May. 15 '58
Bangor May 15 /58
Dear Folks
We arriv'd here about 10 P.M. this morning by the "Daniel Webster, from Portland by R.R. from Boston there - We slept at the "United States,, thursday night I took dinner with Mr. Child - Samuel went out to Newton

I want to know whether Percie has been a real good - & whether he performs his promise every day - am thinking to get him an outside garment - have seen some that I like'd made of light cloth, like that you've got for your Cloak Anna & cut just like gentleman loose overcoats like that Mr. Jenkins wears they look very well - but I forgot to take his measure as I intended.  I suspect I left a nice lace veil that was Lucy's I have no recollection of seeing when I put up my things - I have not unpack'd yet
Completed

Tis best perhaps to let Percie wear his old pant, as much as will do - & not take them away - His grandmother Furber is very smart & fond of display in dress or of making pretension I guess her ways in that do not just suit Samuel he says she is close enough where only comfort is in question - But I suppose they are rich enough to do as they please
I want to caution you a little about letting little Charlie sit to much he does not use his feet enough I took a little child 4 months old that seem'd to jump & use it limbs stand stronger than Charlie But there is no hurry about it if there is not danger of rickets or some weakness consequent upon his being to still

 Irving is quite sick had a fit this morning they thought he ate something that hurt him has a high fever now but will we hope feel much better in the morning poor little fellow he is all mind all
Completed

brain & no body - a little bit of a fellow - little Lucy is thin & small compar'd with Charlie
Sam'l thinks he shall go to Milo and Brownville forepart of next week
Hattie Ely has return'd here and Mary is expecting to go to Binghamton in a week or two or as soon as she can have Company

I hope Percie is a brave good boy & will wash & dress & take care of himself & not trouble others to anything for him that he can do for himself

My head aches some & I feel some tired but not more I expected I should

Sam'l was very kind & attentive as polite as he knows how to be
Sam'l you know was going to surprise the people here - But they knew all about his plans long ago & they were expecting us this very day  Eliab was on the Boat at once had hold of me before I had time to think
Completed

The trees, the face of the earth in general does look dreary here compar'd with your place it is a fact - the trees look naked yet & the grass brown - but the folks & the houses are all right
I feel too stupid to say any thing more to night only pray for me that I may have constantly a present Savior an abiding sense of his encouragement, his love, & Mercy
much love to you all good night
from your Mother

Mother May 1858                 Bangor May 18
My Dear Son Isaac
The spring is backward
it looks cold and dreary here the ground
was frozen considerably yester morn
not withstanding we had on the table
some very nice Radishes of Eliabs own
raising (in a hot bed tho!)
Mary & I have been to the Prayer Meeting.
This morning Eliab's family have
not been much for a week or two since
the children have been sick - Lucy is
considerably better but still so as to
be in Annes lap all the time.  Dear
little Irving is quite sick yet does not
set up at all except in the lap - He is
so little it seems to me not near as big
as Charlie - takes but very little solid food even
when, he is well but drinks much milk.
I don't think he will live many years
there is nothing of him - but he knows
Completed

so much & talks so old  I wish you could see him

I wrote to you Sat. telling "as how" we got here that morning came from Portland in the Daniel Webster  A Mr. Rich who was in the same Carriage I rode up in when E. help'd me in enquir'd if that was my son then began to enquire about you said he was in the Bangor high School with you & I think he said in College two - I ask'd Sam'l this morning about our expenses on the way he look'd over & said my part was 22 dollars  I turn'd right to Eliab & ask'd him if he could lend me some money he ask'd me how much I wanted  I told him 15, 00 would do for I had some  I did n't tell Sam'l how much - I didn't know but I would prefer to my fare in consideration of __ But we must excuse him - he was brought up so
Completed

he never knew except what Lucy taught him by her example any other way but to take & keep whatever was his - you know how good & kind he invariably was to Lucy & his thought probably is that it is my duty & pleasure and duty & pleasure to do everything for Percy the same as it is his - he seems very kind, attentive & loving to me - & probably looks upon it as confessing a favor in letting me have Percy so long & so it is for it was according to my wish & desire to have him with me at whatever sacrifice of self it might - It was Lucys earnest and dying request
Completed

We are all envited to Mr. Kimballs tomorrow morning at 8 o clock to see Sam'l married when he & his wife will start right off to visit at Milo and Brownville - People here think he will have a very good wife I believe Eliab in his queer way says he knows nothing against her only she has too many friends - Anna was speaking of her as being of good family she is acquainted with Mrs. Kimball her Aunt - but another guest Mrs. Theodore Brown is a scandalous or bad woman tis said - Eliza has three Brothers one of whom the youngest I believe got into some mischief here in B. & she had to sell a lot of Land uncle Natty gave her to keep him from prison one of her Brothers lives in Noridgewalk - please not let the children get hold of this letter but read it to Dr & Anna from your loving Mother

I think I shall go to Milo soon probably in a week or two
Completed

Bangor May, 23rd /58
Mr Dear Children
I have written to you once I dont know but twice since I came here_ My head is so confus'd that I cannot tell whether I have given you an account of the wedding which was Wednesday [19] morning at 8 oclock & the Groom & Bride started right off to Milo + Brownville & returnd Friday night_ They spent last evening here_ They expect to go to visit her Brothers Tuesday Wed. & Thursday and calculate to start for home Monday 31st a week from tomorrow probably be at your house Sat 5 of june perhaps sooner I long to know just how Percie has carried himself since I came away I am a little sad now a days I can spare Sam'l but tis like leaving my heart out to give Percie up to them
Completed

Still I know it is all best - best for him & best for me_ I have tried to do, to the best of my ability what Lucy so often & so earnestly requested me to do_ & this tho I have doubtless fail'd often of doing right is my compensation_none but a parent could know the tears I've shed & how I've felt_ May God accepting endeavors & follow the dear boy with his blessing_ I feel thankful to God that I could have him with me so long_ And his Father I guess looks upon it as confering a favor_ Still I know it has been trial vexation, & expense to Anna & you & this you may say no- it is impossible a child for his age could have any family without & I feel as if it would be a happiness to me if I could make compensation But impotency is my inheritance and that which is not naught cannot be
Completed

Tis the Methodist Conference Meeting here now- All the Pulpits here & in Brewer I believe were filled by Methodist Ministers today  Professors Shepard & Harris gone to Boston to the Meetings_ I have been but one morning & two evening meetings- Some of the family did go pretty constantly before I came but both the Children have been sick_ Lucy is considerably better _ Irving is gaining some but is very nervous & unstable. They have to hold him in their laps all day long- have not bee able to get him down on the bed even when asleep in the daytime

Hattie & Mary are both here now Mary is going away to Binghampton next week in Company with S, & his wife- It looks cold & dreary here for the season but it has changed considerably in a week & another week if warm
Completed

will make a very great change Eliab has a Hot bed but he has not sow'd any thing in his garden yet- He has had hand getting along through the "Crisis" he says as the business turned out he gave Sam'l some 4000$ right out 

I guess he has get his business in pretty good shape now but it will take him considerable time to get his debts all paid

My expenses on the journey wire twenty two (22) dollars 
I paid it to Sam'l yesterday
His wife was dress'd very finely today richly & properly the wedding was in very good style I never saw her Aunts except a few minutes there, I was not pleasd with them at all_ She is very well spoken of as far as I have heard_ May God bless you & keep you in the way-do write to me about percie, the meetings, & all the folks,
A. M. Metcalf
Completed

Mother Brownville
July 30 1858
Brownville july 30th /58
My dear Children
I receiv'd a letter from you Isaac & a piece of one from Nettie for which except my hearty thanks - Why does n't Anna write I believe she owes me 2 or 3 letters - I came here 25 of June - have been having a very quiet happy time - not any flies or musketos  I have seen one or 2 musquitos but not near as many as at Elyria last summer
We have had Charles's Mary here about a fortnight & she is really quite a good little girl - I give her a shirt of sewing every day she does it willingly & very carefully & frequently chooses to do considerable more than I set her - They seem to be getting along nicely here Almeda is rather more fleshy than she has ever been before James is doing his haying - has 3 hir'd men there has been a great deal of rainy
Completed

Weather yesterday it was rainy & they all went down to the Lake & they got some very nice Salmon Trout caught for us a dinner - Almeda seems to have fewer anoyances than a most any body & the farm furnishes her every thing she needs  She sold at once last winter 60,00 worth of Butter  they have a fine Stock of Cattle 22 in all - mare & 2 colts owe nothing & all the time plenty of money on hand
I had a letter from Mallie a few days since  She said the children had both been sick but were better
Charles & his neighbor have just been building a School house have got the outside finish'd & painted it is in the Corner of the Webb lot east from Charles's house just a cross the road about 30 scholars in that district a school to commence next month
Completed

Maria seems to think it is not at all probable that she & Eliab will go to Elyria next fall

 you talk my dear son as if it was really decid'd that I am going to Elyria again - now is it best - ought I to go  Almeda says - if I prefer to, but how can I tell whether I prefer to till I know whether I ought to
 If I go it had probably better be a year from next fall It would not be worth while for me to be journeying much both on account of my age & the expense also. If I live to go there it is not to be expected that I should live to return here again & how could I leave all the lov'd ones here never to see them again ___ But it is not of much consequence where I am the little time I have to stay nor do I care much I only want to know what is duty __ I cannot leave my bones in the land of my fathers exactly in either place
Completed

as to the whereabouts for Almeda to locate herself, I am inclin'd to think with you that it may be her duty to stay here she is in a position to do good is lov'd & respected by all her acquaintance - & is among the first in society which society is as a whole far above the society on the reserve (except right in Elyria or similar villages where she would not be able to locate herself) above I say in a social - Moral - intellectual or religion point of view - now is it not so. I only guess besure __ But that is my impression on from the little I do know of the town about Elyria James has look at several places but is not suited with any are having a little talk about the George Wilkins place on top of the Hill near half a Mile south of the Dea Browns price 1600,

 When I got that likeness to send to Percie, I had one taken to send to you & Anna. But as Sam'l did't say or do anything about getting one, I didn't mean that he should know that I had. I put Percies in his Testament & seal'd it up strong & told Samuel not to open it till he got to St. Paul & then give it to Percie & he ought to have minded me. I have here two like that I sent to Percie - for any body that wants them.
 Charles say he should be very glad to go to Elyria but thinks he cannot afford to I intended to write sooner - will try to do better about it in future from your ever loving Mother Much love & good wishes to all the dear ones

[right side] to Dr.  Anna & all their folks why dont Anna write to me
Completed

Mother Bangor
Nov. 18 1858
Bangor Nov 18" 1858
My Dear Son Isaac_ Charles & I came here yesterday in the Chaise very comfortably that the weather is very cold we had a little Snow, 2 inches perhaps, on the 7th of this month & very cold weather ever since the ground frozen very hard it has it has thawed almost none at all even in the middle of the day since
I had a good letter from Anna written the same day that I wrote my last to her I receiv'd yours day before yesterday
In regard to Charlie He would be well pleas'd to go his Father & Mother would be willing his Father would be glad because it would he thinks be great benefit to him_ but there seems to be no opportunity_ Eliab & his wife intend to start their journey about the first week in Dec. And expect to visit
Completed

along at Hartford Easthampton Amherst N.Y. Binghamton & will probably not be at Elyria before the 20 or later perhaps as the last of the month

I am sorry Charlie cannot go but perhaps it will be all best for him to go when I do if you want him I want Anna & the Dr. to think over the plan about coming here and write me as soon as convenient 
They are fashionable Genteel and tastey  as dissimilar to the farm home as the antipodes but I can manage to enjoy it pretty well & "among the Romans to do as the Romans do

But I think if I live a few years longe I shall give up "packing up my duds" to move so often

Your Brother George is expected to take dinner with us thanksgiving day I have not seen him he has call'd here twice & they like him very much they say
Completed

Eliabs fine Vessel launch'd yesterday morning nam'd Mallie Metcalf loaded with ice for Havanna He recievs $1800 freight money this trip_ The little ones seem to be very well now (you wouldn't think they could remain so with their low necks & short sleeves) Lucy eats quite heartily but Irving not at all as I can see- but he drinks a good deal of milk
I am really sorry Charlie cant go, their school is just clos'd & a rather poor school it was & they are to have no more till next summer he really would be very useful to you he is so willing to work & is so honest & faithful & after all he is very dull about any book learning it seem as if he dont know enough to deceive it he wanted to but he will always find out the easiest and the quickest way of doing any work

Almeda talks of buying Charlies red horse & it will be a fine one for her
Completed

it is so kind & so strong we came down in 5 1/2 hours in this hard travelling and the creature has been plowing all the fall_ Charles has got this fall work pretty well done I guess except his new ground which remain till next summer he has 2 great stout men getting out cedar for fencing think he shall try to build a Barn next summer 
please write often & tell Nettie & Anna to likewise
to your ever loving Mother 
Kiss the little boys for me & train them up in the way they should go

Mother Bangor
Dec. 1858
Bangor Dec.
Dear Nettie

 I have not had any of your handwriting this long while - now it cannot be that you think yourself neglected because I have not address'd my letters to you in particular - For what I write to Isaac is just as much to you - you being both one
 I am anxiously waiting to hear from some of you & dont mean to send this till I do.

15th & no letter from our folks yet - Hattie is very much worried with fear that Irving is sick  She expected Mattie would write from, Easthampton & from Hartford
We are all well - little Lucy has never been in better health than just now i e She appears to be in perfect health - She gets her little doll to sleep & then comes to me saying  There There  Then that we need not make a noise - She is a very active child- She wants to have something adoing all the time

 I have heard nothing from Milo since I came from there
Completed

John has just return'd from the P.O. & we have no letters yet - we suppose the folks [Eliab & Maria] get to Binghampton sometime this week if they are all well - but we have some fears that some of them are sick

I do not think much of presentiments & fears & am hardly willing to acknowledge that I had before they went some misgivings - slight fears principally I suppose because they seem'd that their minds were a little too much absorb'd too much drawn away from the straight & rugged way - But probably you'll see them all well & happy sometime next week
I want very much to hear from you all  do please write soon all of you

to your loving Mother
Completed

Bangor Dec 25 1858
Mother M
Elyria
My dear Children
I have been here more than 5 weeks &
have not heard a word from any of you - But I will
"come up with you,, I will keep writing to you till you'll
feel yourselves sufficiently punish'd - I really think
it is too bad.  Your Brother George too is complaining of you Isaac
he say, you never have written much to him.  He was in here
a few minutes this evening - took dinner here.  Thanks giving
& took tea here once since - I like him so does Hattie our
tastes are not very similar in some things, (especially
in the treatment of young Children), but we both like
George at least I do & she says she does & I believe she
means it - but she is very peculiar about talking at
random - I don't know but she can speak the truth.

I suppose Eliab & folks are with you now unless they

are on the way home - we don't get much news from
them there may be a letter in the Office tonight but
we must wait till tomorrow for E carried away one
P.O & Mrs Thurston another - so John has given
up his to Chapman.  Charles was here last week
brought down things & carried home 2 barrels of flour &
various other things family use.  They were all well
Completed

Sabbath eve
I just  spoke with George coming out of meeting
he said he had a letter from Nettie last night - & that
Eliab had been there without Mallie & Irving from which we
infer that Irving is sick & we feel very anxious you may be
sure __  This is the fourth letter - one to Anna one to Isaac
one to Nettie & this - since receiving one word from any of
you - now what will you say for yourselves

I have heard what I thought a very excellent sermon by

Proff Shepard __ But George don't like him or rather he
said he was very much disappointed in him at first - however
it seems to me he must have like'd  the sermon this afternoon
__ I had a good long letter from Samuel
a few days since - he has bought a farm at
Cottage Grove - but I think he will not stay there very
long.  They are boarding with Theodore now. 

Since After he left St. Paul he has had some kind of a

proposal about a steam mill - he did not say he should
accept it but perhaps he will & go back there.
I am so sorry Mallie could not visit you she wanted to so
much.  But I will hope that Irving got well & return'd
there with them - But why have they not written to us
I fear it is because of sickness - It was too much to
shew him off at so many places - & it is lamentable that
the tyrant fashion should be permitted so to torment &
abuse little innocent Children.  Do write some of you-
all of you to your ever loving Mother
Completed

Aug. 2, 59 or 60
Dear Nettie
I am very sorry your Father and Mother
are so unwell hope they will be
better soon. - Do not feel anxious
about us at home at all - we are all
getting along nicely.  The Girls seem to want
to do well but you know Zillah forgets
sometimes a little.  A few days just
after you went away it was very hot
weather & my anxiety about baby and
household matters made me rather weary
& restless a few days, - But have 
got a little used to it now & we all 
think manage better & better.

The little boys do nicely - I have been

up with & wash'd them, both & seen them
into bed every night & without them being
angry or crying once - W. went down to
Dr's Friday came home Saturday P.M as
soon as he got into the house he said
across top, sideways  your fucia has budded and the hydrangea has grown 6 or 8 inches
many new leaves came out since I cut off the great blossom.
I wish I could hand you a pail full of the nice Lawton Blackberries.
Much love and respect to your parents and your Brother
From your ever loving Mother
Completed

Note: letter out of order
grandmother I want my old clothes  I am going to help Father & he went at it as if he could remove Mountains - His Father had been moving - when he came to the supper table he said I dont see how I can stop I must make up that hay - he & Charlie had a fine time one had the garden rake & the other a hoe they made the hay fly

I had written this near a week ago but forgot to put it in Isaacs letter   Charlie's birth day yesterday & he had a long ride with his Father  W stays at the Dr's this week says he is not coming home till saturday night - we are still getting along nicely - the girls do well considering we are two young girls & a superannuated boy 13 years - babys teeth not quite thru'  She is much as she was when you went away we do try to be very careful of her - We have put up 3 cans of blackberries - think we shall not do any more till you get home. Hope you will get strong & well very fast indeed do not think too much about home but enjoy yourself
Completed

Bangor March  n.d.
My Dear Nettie
Will you please accept the enclosed collar it is but a small affair but I thought it might please you merely because I work'd it after I am 72 years old if it is too small you can rip off the binding & do it over it is full'd a little to much into the binding
We are all in usual health - I am expecting to go to Milo tomorrow (Tuesday)  Eliab is going up with me he has business up that way
Your brother George, as I suppose you know, has gone home he seem'd quite unwell when he last calld here I am afraid he is making haste to much - I dont mean exactly that he makes haste to be rich - But I guess he preaches too much
Completed

Hattie is having a fine time seems to enjoy her stay 
here very much it is amusing to see how observant she
is of some things, she already knows the names and
faces of more young men & women and girls too in this place than some
would in seven years with the same opportunity.
But it is not so easy for her to think to learn
& know what she has learn'd - I guess she is very apt
to forget what she has learn'd - she & all of us are thinking
now to have her try to get into the high school - I very much
fear that she cannot pass a regular examination for some 
things required she has not attended to - Eliab thinks it
may be that he can get her in from having Lawyer
Humphrey who is one if the committee in his interest or thro his means somehow

Eliab & Maria are quite interested in Hattie & are trying

to help her E. asks her a great many questions in Geography
& other thing that she cannot answer but calculated to learn
her to think as he says - I have had several promises of letters
from Anna but they don't come - I don't know as I ought to write so 
freely about it.  My only reason is that ye may all be the better able to advise her
Completed

Boston Aug 1835
My dear little boys I suppose you have been wishing for a letter 
from me but not more than I have wish'd to hear from you.  I want
to see you all very much there is scarcely an hour passes but I am thinking
of you - Do try to be good boys do your duty be kind and love one another -
If you have some trials and vexations and if you have
to work hard do try with all your might to be cheerful and good
natur'd all the while - Being fretful and worryin know makes
yourselves and every one about you unhappy and does no good at all.
I want you should tell Charles all your little troubles and difficulty
all you feel and think he will give you good advice and will indulge
your wants as far as is best tis likely - I can hardly enjoy
some of the time I am so much afraid that my dear little Eliab
will grow a naughty boy by going to school without any Brothers or 
Sisters with him to give him good advise & no mother at home to ask
him all what was done at school and tell him what was right and
what was not - but I hope you will all be faithful to one another and
watch over and pray for each other that you may be kept in
the path of wisdom - and O may our almighty Father and friend
keep you from all evil especially from sin the greatest of all evil.
It has been very warm weather here 25 July (Mayo's birthday)
the thermometer stood at 93 in the shade I have felt tolerably well
ever since I've been here but I am not so fleshy nor so strong as I
am usually and Lucy has grown poor and pale has had very little
appetite is not able to do much beside go to school - Ann has
given up her school in Allen  Street because it was all small
scholars and was so fatiguing & her rent so high that she didn't
gain much she has commenced another school for young
Ladies at No 17 Tremont St.  price of tuition 4 to 10 dollars
and has a prospect of doing pretty well by & by - James is all
taken up with the antislavery affair there is a great deal of
excitement upon that subject but I suppose you learn more
from the newspapers about it than I can tell you there is a great
excitement about Popery also I have understood that there are
Completed

a large number of truckmen and others in the city that are determined to
celebrate the coming of the convent they are preparing an Efigy of
the Lady Superior with which they mean to march round in the
streets of the city and out to Charleston as near the convent ground as
they can get and then shoot it and tis expected that there will be
an irish mob if they should - a Mr. Mc Calla has been delivering
lecture at Park Street exposing the evils of Popery and Mr. Pepper
Edelor of the Cath Centinel and other Catholics tried to
interrupt the meeting but could not make out - I intended to have
finished this letter and sent it last week but could not - Almeda has
not been well you know this long time for several days she has been very sick and
yesterday she had a daughter born a very fine looking child but it is
dead - her health is improving more and I think of going in to 
the country in 3 or 4 weeks if she gets along well.  I want very
much Joseph that you should come here and go with me but
I don't know as it will be expedient for you to come so soon because
of the work at home Charles will have so much to do but you may
be thinking about it that will do no harm if you should not come do
try to be a good boy keep yourself neat and clean do wash your face and
neck clean as often as twice a day at least all of you.  I had a while
ago considerable thought of having you Isaac come too this winter &
go to school at Andover where Caleb is there is a good school and very cheap.
I suppose I could get a chance there where the whole expense for board
and tuition would be more than a dollar a week but on the whole
I do not now think it best the expense of getting here and back would
be so much and Eliab would be left almost alone but you
must certainly go to school somewhere so do try to be a very good boy
that Charles may be the better able to spare you - Almeda think
I had better go to Warwick and stay 2 or 3 months and then come back &
spend the winter here but I have not concluded whether I shall go to
Milo this fall or not - I have not been to Lowell or Woonsocket or
anywhere else scarcely since I came here what is the reason Isaac
that you have not written do set right about it and write me a good
long letter - Almeda wants Lucy to stay with her 2 years or more
right side provisions? are very high there this summer but [page torn] 28 for him 23 cents
Completed

have just receivd your letter Eliab I feel somewhat distress'd about Joseph  I have been expecting he would be sick  Sorry he took a lobelia had much better came right home I sent your Pants Jacket and 2 pr stockings by Mr Severance last week I suppose you got them sameday you wrote to me - I couldnt make them very well with very coarse thick cloth but I guess theyll do, write to Isaac very soon he complains bitterly of neglect  I send down a lot of butter most all of it very good that in the white box is super excellent but perhaps not quite salt enough to keep long I dont know how much there is it ought to be a 1//ath, I want you should give Ann $2 out of the avails of it if there is so much & you may have what is over if any __ we are knitting some gloves and stockings for J. and you - Give my love to Mrs Brown and thank her for me for taking care of my boys

 Dear Son Joseph  E. says you have been unwell I have expected it, that you are taking Lobelia I am afraid tis not best I think you need relaxation, rest, do now Joseph come right home you had better leave your work now a few days  than be oblig'd to leave it for months perhaps give it up entirely they can do without you a few days I know - I know that it is important for a young man to establish a character for attention to business  &c &c but attention to ones health is certainly more important if you are able to come home come you'll gain it in your business for you cant succeed in it if you are not well we have heard The Typhus fever is very prevalent ant very malignant in B. about this time - Do write to Isaac I feel very anxious about him not partly because he feels so nicely about building a school house dont know what to say but it seems that she must have a little help or her school must fail & C & you & E must help. C thinks perhaps he could get Gilman to go & do the work a dollar a day had n't you better come home with C I think you had They can get somebody else or do without a few days

17th Feb 1848

Very Dear Son

 I regret some things I wrote in my last letter (we dont always feel alike, besides

did not mean to be taken so much in earnest & you know I always
express myself too strongly __ I think that I at least do not
much misunderstand you - can sympathize (as Albina says, with
you in regard to being misunderstood and also in regard
to unsociableness if that is the right word for it I rather think it
is not - I have often (tho' not quite as much lately as years ago), stay'd
away out of the room when I had company as long at a time as it 
would do to just because I was asham'd and mortified that I couldn't
bear my part in conversation.  Anybody who can write like you cannot plead inability to converse.  But there are always some persons
with whom I could be perfectly free and sociable - I think I 
myself was in fault & have tried to get the better of it - Still & believe
with you that what is call'd social intercourse is not always enjoyment
I regret because my letter made you sad -- " I did have in view not
so much to teach, (tis too late to use that word I need to be taught as you)
to be happy an to try to make others so. - I take the liberty 
to doubt whether the best way for you to make others happy is
to keep out of their way - Do you wish to have your friend all
keep out of your way - Are there not benefits in social gatherings -
Why were the Jews to Congregate together three time
a year.

 I am much the most likely not to be understood because have

not the use of language wherewith to express my poor 
confusd ideas __ you have very clear ideas very few persons can
express themselves better in writing - If your mind is like a rich
mine is it not your duty to fetch it out for the use of your fellow
creatures - Well whatever else we do may we at last find a seat
in that Great assembly where mind meets mind without a clog or 
cloud between.
Completed

19th Feb Saturday night 10 o' clock

Ever Dear son Eliab 
Have made one pair of your shirts the
coarse ones we have been rather busy this week but wanted
to, and did finish one for because of such a good opportunity
to send em - your thread was hardly good enough & not
enough of it but it is just as well as we had enough.

Lucy is the girl to make bosoms & collars I wish you would

look at Josephs and just see how nice they are.

Any time when you or Joseph want shirts (not if they have

linen Bosoms tho') I should esteem it a privilege to make them.

In regard to settlement that Joseph said something about

what can I say or do - hadn't I better let it all go I doubt not
that C. would willingly supply me with whatever he thinks.
I need as long as I live if he has the means of doing it even if
it should take a much greater amount of property than belongs
to me.  He may not always, feel so but I guess he would.

Perhaps I had better leave it all with him - Trusting -

He is in the hands of an overruling God.

If I should live to see the time when I cannot labor I might

feel more dependant than would be agreeable to such a proud
spirit as mine - but if it is best I think I can bring myself
to it - We have said almost nothing about it since last July and
have hardly thought it (I don't love to think of it) but as I am upon it
I'll answer Josephs question as far as I can - The title is rested in
me without any mortgage or draw back, is legally perfected by registry.

I have an impression that the note was for 12 hundred dollars

and that it was given 10 or more years since but I have not
seen it since nor said anything about it or known where
it is - it was witness'd I think by Henry B Sargent.
It isn't best to think it a matter of any consequence for you all know
that I cannot be willing to have anything like grand or hard
thoughts
Will you take an early opp to return this as 
I wish to reply to it now while flush of leisure & short of cash.

Oct 11th

My very Dear Sons J & E
You must know that Mrs. Sargent & Almeda & others
have with considerable labor & anxiety & exertion collected
together money & wool enough or nearly to purchase some broad cloth for
a "Pall cloth, they think of sending to request you to get it for us    13  2 yards wide 4 cord & tassells
if they do - do your best & get that which will not fade - Charles's 
wedding coat which should have been a handsome coat thus 5
years is so faded that it is all one spoil'd.

 C. has sold his oxen or rather bargained them away to a Mr. Doe

of Ormville - lives near Mr. Keane's - for 75'00 next April - has heard
since that the man is not worth anything do you know anything about him.

He talked of going to H & Bangor this week but there is always some

bad luck you know - Nelly is very lame one leg smelled very
bad & broke out in sores can't go a step, i.e don't take her out of the barn
yesterday got in the last of his corn how much rainy weather
we have had - I guess he will hire a horse and go in about 10 days or
week after next will if he goes at __ Mr H. Sargent is very much pleased with
his Barrel of flour says it is a little the best that ever he had.

C&A sold sheep to Eddie Lord for money & sent the money by

him to get each a Barrel of flour Gass? was no better than
common scratch'd flour Almeda's is so bad that she wont use
it __ Eliab I have had my right arm lame a little most all the 
time since I was last in Boston never expect to perform just
such a feat again ha! ha!  Wasn't you lame with having such
a weight hanging on you - I felt so shiftless I forgot to enquire
after your feelings at the time - Tell Lucy - very much obligd
for the dress it was just what I needed what a blessing it is to
have good children.
Completed

I am some afraid Albina will be disappointed of her ride
and visit you must know that Esq Rich has not taken his
young wife out a ride for pleasure scarcely since they were married.
She has got her 10,00 at last is going to get her a new shawl therewith.

I suppose you have heard of the tranquil end of Mr. E Severance

a strange occurance.

You may send me half 1/2 lb Tea good when you have convenient opportunity

C got some ink no matter about the other things.
Albina is going to have the dress I had of you Joseph
as it is not quite so suitable for me - I shall send you a few pairs
of stockings, & gloves perhaps if you can dispose of them and as
fast as you can get a fourpence in that way you may put it
to Isaacs's credit - he ought to have some pay "every little helps a
little, as the wren said, I shall have the satisfaction of trying to do
something.

Charles is to let his oxen go in a fortnight if the man brings

such security as will satisfy him, if you know of any names
to do better please inform.

Eliab why don't you write to me do write soon.

When are you & Joseph coming home you will come before
winter won't you __ I had a letter from Brother Nathan
Sister Lois died the 4th of Sept the day after she was 50 years old.

I want to see Isaacs letter to Lucy he did not write me anything

about his sickness I have many fears for him when he is
sick tis most always his head he has been treated 2 or 3 times I
think with that dreadful disease brain fever he makes too light
of sickness - warn him to take care of himself he thinks he has 
an iron constitution but this all appeared all made up of habits he
may venture to far before he is aware he was born a feeble child has not
the natural constitution that most children have

I thank Samuel and you for your letter go on in ways of well doing.
To my Lucy Dear Daughter
The cloth for dress was very acceptable
just what I need, am very much obliged don't know as I can
get it made up till you come - can tho' if I try doubtless
little Charlie Metcalf has been unwell ever since I come
home is better now a few days - there don't seem to be much
time to work Albina means to get her a nice shawl all
circumstances considered I should rather wait till next
fall I think - she could put her money at interest you know
where she could have it then but however the may want to
wear it a few times - I have to talk to C. & Albina about

I came home she had not a very good appetite in the hot

but she can't keep from fretting about her work - the baby
has been & is very good but she would think she has wondrous

Jane is very healthy now eats as much as a man almost is
real smart driving round in the house and out too I believe she

October 11 1848
you'll find in the bundle your Book paper etc. Bills for Lucy

Joseph & Eliab & Lucy
[right-hand side] Charles was going to take the Cow down to pay for the stove if his horse had not been lame this week if you could happen to mention the reason why he did not to Mr. Noyse the store man it might prevent some difficulty perhaps Charles said he didn't know but he ought to write to him but he is so busy I dont believe he will

July 2nd
My Dear Son I thank you for your good letters to myself  & Ann-your letters generally have
to much of incoherency & appearance of hurry about them whether it is for the want of time or
to show that you are a "business man" I don't know but I think tis usually best to give yourself time
enough to do whatever is worth doing at all - however I am very glad of anything from either of you.
Eliab has hardly written a word except what pertain'd to business & was absolutely necessary since he
went there perhaps he don't have time but it seems to me he ought to - I am afraid you work a 
little to hard or take to little rest and allow yourself to get nervous - take care and keep yourself cool
calm & steady - you are too sensitive and finespun to get along well in the crowd and stand your
ground among all the bustle & rebuffs that are unavoidable in a business life but you must
try to toughen your feelings and train yourself to it or stretch your feeling give way and let
other people do as they please without being disturbed by it what if you are among
subject to the "beck and bidding" of such as you discribe try to be humble and faithful
act the part of christian and you will find in almost everyone something that is
amiable and lovely you to much reasonable the misanthrope try to think much of your
own fault but be very charitable to the faults of others you are fond of order and method
and is in well to be so but do not let it carry you so far as to be fidgety by the want
of it in others you will accomplish more business and do it better if you allow yourself 
sufficient rest and relaxation than if you keep yourself in a fever all the time with
every nerve strained - if you've got a good place don't get unease with it the
initiating or probationary state is in any case a state of trial & the greater the
trial the more find and fit for use the subject of it will be
and if you are really gaining what will be very useful to you in after 
life I would not grudge the time if you get but small wages a year or
even 2 or 3 soon pass away but I stop this strain of advise lest your patience
should quite exhausted but one thing I want you should that is
an errand to Mr Brown I was going to write to him, but can't well spare time
it is to ask him to spare Eliab a few day and let him come home
with Charles, tell him I do want to see my baby very much indeed he never has been
gone so long from me you know before, besides I think he absolutely needs to have
a few days or his health will suffer by it - it would be very bad for him to be sick there
& if he should come home and the fresh air and relaxation might prevent it
Mary says tell him to come do I want to see him you cant think how she does enjoy
herself flying about like a squirrel among the cows & calico pigs & chickens: Strawberries
etc. riding on Cate & Donkey she has inform'd herself more now about all the matters &
things on a farm, than Ann would in a year she lives upon strawberries & milk has grown
fat and smart - I expected C. would go last thursday but it rain'd so that he could not go tell
E that it will be just in good time for strawberries next week and do try to have him come.
written across letter I meant to inquire about price of wooll but haven't had time Will if I can I express in figures on back or face of letter
Completed

This an unfinished incoherent mess which is not worth
your reading only I want you think read it for the sake of my ?
to Mr Brown tell E to come if he can twill do him good
Charles just had another letter from Jessie? I just recd a letter from Isaac
Charls has been talking and considering about going to Bangor but he can't make out
to get anything to pay debts with or to buy the lots
of the things we need  we have 30 or 40lb of butter but that wont do much
he think now that he shall go down thursday and see Mr J & D but it will
not be of much use as I can see.  July 7th

Mother July 2 1845
To Joseph M Metcalfe

July 29th 1845
I should be glad to write a long letter to you & Eliab I owe one to Isaac
too but I have neither time nor a single sheet of paper to write on
if I had I have thought for 2 or 3 summers past that I never could work
so hard another summer but it  comes harder and harder almost - it
will become the 'by and by' & I have got along with it better than I expected -
Our folks began haying today Charles is most sick I don't
see how they will ever get done for L tho a good steady fellow is but a 
boy.  Most people about here began last week but they had better not
for it has been rain rain rain they lose their labour and hay besides.
I send this I suppose with A's bucket of Eggs by the way they are part mine
& five dozen of these all which you may take to yourself it may be
I shall pay you all up sometime or other at least I shall try the last
wax I sent I meant to send to you but forgot to tell Charles I don't know
he could if I had for he had nothing to get anything with & I can't get along without
as I cant if I had not boarders [A tells me she has paid the 63 cents]
I feel bad very bad that we can't among us all help Isaac enough to enable him
to stay next term - I get Charles to say that he'd let him have the old oxen
this fall but I don't know as they would be saleable C. has swapt of the steers and
got a yoke of the same age which he thinks would sell better at 6 dollars to boot
If tis convenient for you I wish you or Eliab would get a good loud cowbell
and I'll send some butter when the weather is cooler it takes Sam'l or C an hour or
2 every night to find the cows and often not till the next day most noon
all the cattle [14] got up to Mr Crosbys once and he drove em off to pound cost
6 7 or 8 dollars - when are you coming home if you and E are got fixd so
Completed

right there that you never can get away a much I shall wish you
had never gone there do write more both of you
why don't you tell me whether you got  those records I sent you
by Benj Speering and send them back or take care of them, till you
come I have no copy of them.
Joseph Metcalf
