Milo Nov 3rd 1849
My own Dear Son, I receiv'd your letter Monday eve with joy and gladness. I rejoice that you got through your journey so Comfortably also that you have found such agreeable Company as Mr. Dole - perhaps you will find other very agreeable companions if you will allow yourself to be acquainted with them
You speak of "Actual Comfort" - I cant conceive of any such thing as actual comfort pack'd in a cold wet sheet at 5 o'clock in the morning - Compared with Snoozing in a good warm bed
Is n't it horrible wicked to be so dreadful lonesome as I am when I can have the pleasure? of Albinas Company all to myself day after day - Tis She that has the worst of it for she has all the talking to do
I am always dull & stupid about talking you know but I can hear pretty well -- is clever and kind hearted not withstanding some fret and disagreeableness & I have much reason to be thankfull 
When you write to Isaac tell him to come home at Thanksgiving and take you along on his way you will have found out by that time how to "Treat" yourself with cold water and can carry it on at home (by the way what is the temperature of the water you are treated with) perhaps your present Home and present Mother could do you more good but it will be more expensive however you ought not to mind that if it is really better for you
Completed

Tuesday morning 6th

Charles went down to Hampden in the morning Stay'd about an hour & got home the same day about 6 oclock. Did bring the "leetle Cane,, and some nails - & some onions they are proper good - and exceeding Cheap - 60 cents pr bushel you have heard I suppose that Dr. Snow is dead  Mr. Dow is yet alive. Mrs. Aaron Tolman died yesterday 

   Monday night a week ago A Family Moving from Ossipee N.H. to Aroostock stopt here and stay'd here during the rain Tuesday - paid 2.00 - you know I suppose that Lucy has not got to housekeeping yet is going to move into the Harthorn house. I had a letter from Isaac last night. Charles had one from Eliab about selling Oxen to Benjamin Hurd of Harmony - but he has not made his appearance yet. Mr. Gilman is to work in the East room Charles hurrying round getting ready to work with him. Mrs. Richer sick - Albina gone there so I have to be cheif Cook & bottle washer.
   I suppose you have inform'd Isaac of your whereabouts he will be much surprise'd. He says he shall certainly come home but cannot tell when _ I hope you can come when he does i.e. if it it is best for you to 
 May God bless you my Son and restore you to perfect health__ May you feel to acquiese and say from the Heart Thy will be done whatever that will may be   your Mother
Completed

Milo Dec. 17th 1849

My Dear Son I recieved yours of Nov. 27 was very glad indeed to hear from you but had rather do without having than have you labor too hard by writing your indignation at Charles's treatment of Rickers folks was in a measure ? ? or rather he think you are under a mistake Ricker & his wife would have been very angry would have scorn'd him forever had he done any such thing C. paid the nurse Mrs. R. is very well Mr. R. has gone a fortnight brought him a Barrell of ? - has not found any chance to go into the woods but gets plenty of work about here and good pay So I guess he'll rub along. As far as you are concern'd I'm quite inclin'd to be glad your Ague didn't burst for I do not believe in the douche being good for you. Now Joseph I do want you should come home or come to Hampden. If the W. Treatment has not very perceptably benefited you yet what reason have you to suppose it will & if it does not Benefit it certainly does injure I believe there is very real Efficacy and Benefit in the use of Cold Water But after all I rather think that Cold Water Doctors ought to be round'd with Steam Doctors Rainwater Doctors & other one idea folks.

 I dont believe that it was ever intended that Man should live by Water alone. Or how can people live and enjoy health in regions where it is impossible to immerse or douche themselves
 I am thinking to go to Hampden in a week or two if I can and I hope to find you there. Your Habits have been such from your youth up that there cannot be much in your spleen that needs be wash'd out 
 As you say there seems to be a strength in you notwithstanding your weakness that is very encouraging

[upside down at top]when you want to come will not Isaac come to accompany you if you let him know - or Eliab if he dont or possibly Eliab & Lucy I should even like to myself if it didn't cost anything but do come soon unless you are satisfied that you are recieving benefit by staying there May God be with you My Son & bless you in all your doings. A.M.M.
Completed

Dec. 17 1849

 Mother

And gives me reason to believe that Nature will Eventually conquer the disease. Perhaps you will have to wait long. But if you do not have to suffer much pain so that you can enjoy your mind, that is surely great cause for Thankfulness.

  We had rather a lonely Thanksgiving. I spent the day with Almeda & her children. Had a very good dinner. Mr. Kittredge & wife were invited here to dinner & spent evening C. had not done his Butchering as usual before but had a fat goose (for roast Beef & for a turkey) and some chickens etc. etc. He has kill'd his Twin Creature which was neither Male nor female. But decidedly the best Beef that I ever tasted - they gave away about 50 weight of it Almeda, Rickers etc. Did Dr. Deanes head drop off? or mere appearance decietful? We have a very little Snow about here and people ride in Sleighs some but it is better wagoning than sleighing I should think. Semianual Conference at Brownville tomorrow & the next day. I want to go but dont know as I can.
 Almeda has been afflicted with the Rheumatisms of late in her neck arms and shoulders. She limps considerably but can go without crutches Sam'l and Eliab have just given her a Barrell of Flour - "Good boys well done,,
Mehitable teaches the Small School at the Village John has gone to Hampden Academy Board with Sam'l. I'm afraid it will make it too hard for Lucy to (come comb his hair put on his dicky & brush his Coat every day) But perhaps she'll learn him better. Gilman has gone away a while to attend to his family and let the plastering dry he says being plaster'd in cold weather it will hardly be safe to sleep in the bed Room till spring he is coming again next week to stay till it is done or till he pays up his debt will probably do something to the chamber as far as C. has got the Lumber etc. to do it with. I want to know when you calculate to leave Waterford.
Completed

Saturday morn  Hampden Oct. 26
 Ann has not arrived yet we hope this days Boat will bring her.
  I dont know hardly what to say to you about poor Lucy. I think she is very sick. The Dr. says she is very sick he told her at first he didn't want to alarm but that she was sicker than she thought herself to be. She has had very high fever pulse from 120 to 130 and exceeding sore all around her stomach & back with very hard cough and dry till today she raises a very little. There seems to be a Change in her Symtoms a little since yesterday She has slept more & has cough'd less seems not so feverish Night before last she scarcely slept at all has such very severe pain in her head back and right side & shoulder she couldn't lay in bed stay'd on the sofa changing her position every 2 or 3 minutes. She or Sam'l dont appear to be very much alarm'd. Perhaps the change in her symtoms is indicates a favorable crisis in her fever. We shall see whether the fever comes on again at night.
  John Furber came here Thursday was half sick has been taking medicine. I cannot tell when I had better go home. She says Almeda would be next, of all the world to come here to take care of her but that it seems as if she couldn't have me go. we'll hope she has begun to get better I'll write more tomorrow morning.
 All her difficulty the Dr. says is occation'd by inflamation on the lungs. If that can be remov'd I suppose
Completed

all is well but Lung Fever & Dr. says hers is of the worst kind is always I suppose attended with considerable danger. O such a dreadful hard harsh cough if she speaks a single loud word (she talks in a whisper). Evening the Dr. here at 5 thinks Lucy's Symtoms a little more favorable she begins to expectorate & that is what he has been trying for says if she can get to raise freely it will relieve her Lungs. I think I shall not go home monday at any rate & I cant tell just when but I think of Dear Joseph not a little.
Dr. MCruen seems very gentle & careful with her he bled her a little at first. tonight we put a slight blister on her stomach - I suppose? you are glad to have me there particular
Sabbath morn Lucy is certainly somewhat reliev'd but is very weak and sore can speak but very little, and only in a whisper, because of her cough. You will perhaps be fearing that it is to hard for me. I have been weary some time with watching etc. but I have endured it wonderfully (she slept more last night than she has before) I slept good the last part of the night or rather this morning & I feel well & strong. If Lucy recovers as fast as we could reasonably expect she must not, cannot work for a long time to come. Eliab was down here this morning, has gone to see if he can get a girl Mary Becroft that they think very much of to come and stay a while till Ann comes perhaps. Almeda must probably come when I go home, which possibly may be Wednesday if not I'll write then let her be preparing herself (which she will need to do about clothes & in many points with all dispatch. I suppose that you Joseph will enjoy it quite
Completed

as well to have Lucy or Jane with you to take care of the fire, cut up your food etc & Almeda be there only a few minutes in the morning, and so make it easy for Albina as you can. She has got as much as she ought to do.

 Sam'ls Mother is expected to come Tuesday and be here while she is recieving the Doctors attention. She is lame but can probably help some, if she does it seems that she must be somewhere else. Eliab has returned could not get the Girl he went after - but I think it is perhaps just as well.
 Do give Joseph every attention that he needs, I dont know why I say it I have no doubt but what you will.
 I will go and consult about going home & see if we can determine any thing
 you will of course get this monday eve- write every thing I want to know send by Mrs. Furber who comes on the stage I suppose. Send also a paper of Catmint, which may be found by looking on the South end of upper shelf, closet in east room. also if to be had, Almeda's Syringe large one - possibly I may come home Friday & Almeda come Saturday write all about what you think about it. Lucy must have the most vigelent care the lease "pull back" would place her beyond recovery.
 why dont Ann come? one of Almeda little Blankets if convenient but no matter Lucy worries some about J says she dont want to be selfish but she dont now how she can bear to have me leave
Completed

Hampden Sundy Eve

Dear Br. Joseph

   I beleive mother has written what can be written about Lucy. perhaps she feels more discouraged about her than the as will warrant I feel confident that she is better than she was a few days since, am very sorry that I could not get someone to come & stay with her. Mary Beacroft would come but her brother James is very sick. I am not acquainted with any other person who would be just right.
 Crescent Division have voted to appropriate 50$ for a library. I am one of a committee to select Books, what shall I select, Your "Temperance Tales" are here would you not like to present them to the division? please write by first Mail & send me a list of such books as you think would be good ones. also about the "Tales"
                                                                        Good bye
                                                                                           Eliab

[upside down] Mother Hampden

              Oct. 26, 1850
Completed

My Dear Grandson I want to give you a little advice & I hope you will take it kindly. I was greiv'd & asham'd to see you so trifling & full of little monkey tricks in Sabbath School. Now I want you should think about it. wouldn't it be better for you to be a quiet serious boy, Noble & sensible a fit example for the rest of your Class than to greive & disgrace your Parents & get the name of being the most troublesome boy in your Class- as I heard that your teacher said of you Do my dear boy - think of it - & rejoice my heart by becoming the best boy in your Class
Completed

Elyria Dec. 1st
My dear Son Charles
  Why is it that I do not have a letter from you & Albina? Charlie enquires almost every day he ask'd me the other day if I didn't think the the house had burnt down or something happened? He seems contented & happy enough uniformly Cheerful I have not seen him angry once but 2 or 3 times when thinking about home he has had to cry because he wanted to see the folks so he said  that was some weeks ago he didn't like to have the folks know it but I found it out & talk'd with him about it. He gets along nicely in school - they have the short lessons and are requir'd to get them exactly & thoroughly at the examination for the last month He rank'd 100 per cent (i.e. perfect) in deportment & 96 in scholarship
 Mary is so ladylike & proper in her behavior that you would hardly know her at any rate you would be amused sometimes to see her --she reads better than Charlie tho' he has learn'd to read a good deal better than he did. He is a good boy he gets up easily keeps his face, hands, neck & teeth clean does his chores all up nicely & quickly without stopping or being told & very Cheerfully perhaps he does a little better for having me to look out for him & prompt him. 

I am afraid that you need him at home to help you. But if Joseph takes right hold as smartly as cheerfully & as faithfully as C. does you have good help
Completed

But do take care of your health - dress warm & comfortably & decently & allow yourself good patalatable food well cook'd I believe it would be good for you to eat more good fat beef as we do have plenty of good Beef has been sold in this vicinity $3,00 & 3.50 per hundred I save you 3 dollars for a quarter of very extra fat & nice   Very best Corn is 25 cents a bushel on the Cob poor - inferior- is 15 or 16 cents  .25 cts per bu. on the Ear 50 cts. shelled. Isaac says that a man can make more raising it at that price than they could in Maine at the price it is worth there.

Dec. 19th I begun this letter some days ago, before recieving yours of the 4 of Dec. We were very glad to get the letters (by the way they might all have come in one envelope) I had letters written 24 Nov. from Eliab, Mallie, Mary Ely, & Hattie DeWitt all in one. If you would write oftener it wouldn't be so much of a task to you. There is scarcely anything that happens about the family the house the barn or the farm or the neighborhood, but would be interesting to me to know. And I want to write anything to you just as I would talk but I fear to have my letters laying round for everyone to read. I wish you would put them away somewhere or burn them.

 I am very glad that Mary Kittredge is going to board with you on several account. I hope it will do you both good. I fear that in consequence of living there so much you'll grow narrow minded sordid & fretfull not to say boorish & uncouth. I beg that you will
Completed

for the sake of your children if you care nothing about it for yourselves try to keep up with the times you are so unfavorably situated for cultivating the social feelings - the amenities of life - & learn so little of the great benevolent & religious apperations of the age. That you ought to make the more exertion - visit more see more company get your mind & heart more embued with love & kindness to your fellow creatures __ I think Charles that partly for lack of opportunity & more perhaps by neglect of opportunity you have fail'd of filling the sphere that your native power of Mind requir'd of you you have a strong - an appreciative mind a discrimination & correct judgment - But from timidity & lack of exertion you have kept yourself too much shut up within yourself. But tis not too late, rouse yourself use yourself, tis never too late to mend, to try to grow better - with a mind stay'd on God a filial trust & confidence in the merciful Redeemer. I can speak feelingly on this subject having been so very delinquent myself.

 I do so want to see the children and all of you I wish we could live near each other the little time I have to live. I feel contented & comfortable but I often think of my good pleasant room at home & should like to be there now and then an evening & see you & Albina come in & sit & tell over the events of the day.

25
Completed

I am glad you read Beechers Sermons
we do the same - have just been reading the one 
in the paper Dec 15th
This term of school closes at the end of this week there will
be 2 or 8 weeks vacation - Mary's travelling dress as she
calls it is so short for her now that it will be of no
more use to her - I can percieve that she has grown tall & Charlie too unless we take out a breadth a peice is
down & that would not look very well.

 Charlie wants answers to a great many questions

he wants to know about Jane - Anna - George Reves
& how every thing is getting along all round there &
at the village  wishes Cally would write to him
in particular he wants to know how much
corn you rais'd - says he wishes Joseph would
sell the Beans & the potato's they rais'd east of Mr
Sargents & send him part of the money
He paid 75 cents for the Likenesses but I don't know
but we shall pay it back to him __ I have furnish'd
money for Mary - for mending shoes, 50 for Apron &
knit worsted cloak or large cape the Dr got at
Cleveland 1,50 (& she must have a pr of shoes soon 1,50) her Books also, I don't know just how
much the were till I ask Anna - we are all well
except Nettie has a bad cold Baby is a little fat plump
thing weigh 21 pounds sits alone but dont Creep yet.
I have heard by way of Bangor the joyful news that
James & Lizzie have given themselves to Christ have obtain'd
hope but Almeda has not written me a word about it &
wonder why - Has she been at Milo lately - has she taken
the things, that I left for her in the Bureau drawer
what have you done with "Pug" - do write - much oftener
write more to your Mother
Completed

Brownville June 25

My Dear Son Charles
I want you or Albina should write to me
while James is gone - Tell me if you have been into the school is
it a good school & all about it - & all about the S.S does Mrs S.
feel "interested" - does Mrs. Billington attend have you
been to see her yet.  I forgot to tell you that Hattie Ely
said that they had got a new Straw Carpet for the
West Chamber & that you or Almeda can have the old one
if you think it is worth sending for - they would be glad to 
have it brought out of the way - there would be enough
that's good to cover a bedroom floor.  Almeda would send for
it if you don't want it as her bedroom is not painted ?.
Besure & tell James whether you want it or not.
Would not you do well to come and make your visit here soon
as convenient & then send the Lion & Chaise down for Eliab
to use a while & for Maria to come up &c.
I wish you would in your talk to and about the boys get
them to believe   that you have great confidence in them.
If they feel that you think them correct in their behavior
it will have a tendency to make them so - Try to have
them willing to tell you everything they say & do - in order
to do it, sympathize with them in all their little plans &
plays   Charles will you read the enclos'd letter
to the boys, faithfully get the their attention -
don't put them down but encourage them & try to get them to
Completed

feel and to hold themselves above doing anything mean
or improper.
I hope you can come up here how you did sit a read your
papers all the short time you were & hardly spoke a word when
you had not seen your sister for months.
Lizzie gets along nicely with her school she has several
that could say their letters that have learned them all & can
read in reading & spell small words has from 15 to 20
& I guess she governs the school nicely - Judiciously.
She has to help her mother a good deal they have seven Cows
& there are seven Milk pails to wash & scald & I can't tell you
how many pans every day Churn 4 time a week &c &c

 Louise is a very good little girl & a good scholar don't need any 

watching & looking after she has stitch'd this morning & with very fine stitches
more than half a yard without being put up to it at all - & with
out any thimble james is going to get her one tonight - tell mary
L has almost made her a pr of drawers this week beside going to school
& she does a good many Chores & some times washes the dishes
tell her if she'll be the best girl in the school all this summer
I'll make her a present - don't forget to give Josie
that cent that I forgot to give him
Send the bag that is behind my bedroom door by
James & write - write
Don't forget the bag for all my old
thin dresses are in it & I have
wanted it every day.
Completed

My Dear Son        Jan 29 1853
I want you should read "Voice of Nature"
but still I don't know as you would like it indeed
I know you won't care much about it unless you
will give considerable thought to it - But there is that
& so much other excellent reading - I do grudge to have
you spend so much time in singing - tho' I love
singing, & think it pleasant, delightful & improving
even, to the Mind - But you have so little time to
read, and your "Seed time" is gone, your Summer
partly past - the Autumn of your life is close upon you__
are all your habits of thinking and ?ething
and all your knowledge of virtue holiness and heaven
just as you would have them and all that you would
wish them to be when you enter on the confines
of Eternity.  All and just such as you wish to be
the Cast and Mould of your Sons & your Sons, Sons.
I feel with keen regret the loss of time - tho'
my opportunities have not been great yet if I had
improv'd all as I might with faithfulness & energy
how much more knowledge how much more spiritual
mindedness I might now have to rest upon as I go
down to the valley of the Shadow of Death.
O Charles do not follow my example when I have
been so wanting in duty - but let go of the triffling
Completed

perishing things of this world - And dig deep and
earnestly for the things that will endure the things
that will bring with them peace & never ending happiness

 With the arms of faith yet firmer, fasther hold on

Him, who has said - "He that cometh unto me I will in
no wise cast out."  And having Him you have all, all.

 I would not be understood that I think

you more than most others are all absorb'd in the petty
cares & insignificant concerns of this life - But is not
there a monstrous disproportion or inconsistency with us all
in our care for things of time & sense & neglect of those that
will last & will form our Characters for eternity, eternity.
Feb 1st Mr. C A Everett & his wife visited here last
Friday how different he appears from what he did -
He was sedate and dignified but perfectly gentlemanly
affable & agreeable I cannot but hope he is in some
respects at least a different character from that 
he was before he went away.

 Eliab talks some about going to Milo but perhaps

he will not as Mr Haskins his partner is going to
Washington in a week or two and then he can not
leave the business  Eliab expects to be married
in April - he writes to Maria every week and
she to him every week, he writes every Saturday she
every Wednesday
Completed

we were very sorry that Samuel could not carry the things that we had got ready to send we've had no chance since

   Anna call'd on a Lady of her acquaintance to get a Saque pattern & she gave her the lining of a Sacque  Said you could cut one by it better than by a pattern I should think it would be just the thing for a lining for Charlie's I would make it large for him the little boys here all wear them very large and loose I hope you have not already got it cut
   Do write Albina  do write Charles to 
                                       your Mother A.M. Metcalf

Feb. 5th We are all here Mr. Rider has just arriv'd Mr. White Sam'l's Teamster call'd this forenoon, did not bring the Cider  forgot it because he had a Sick man to bring - Mr. French of Ormville __ I am sorry for Charlie's Boil. But hope it has got well by this time

  Your Children are so liable to have bad humours Do I entreat you not let them eat so much greasy potato It cant be much more work to give them bread & Milk & if they live they would be willing to thank you a thousand times as I should be glad to my parents for feeding me as they did - if they have nothing but bread & Milk for breakfast & supper it will not hurt them if they have enough of that
